Generation of a calibration file for 3D data
, J., Schoen, I., and Ries, J. (2018). Real-time 3D single-molecule localization using experimental point spread functions. Nature Methods 15, 367–369.
Acquire z-stacks of 10 – 20 different FOV of beads with the following settings:
∆z = 10 nm (also higher values like 20 or 50 nm can be used for faster acquisition
acquisition in conventional gain (to increase the signal to noise ratio)
Launch the calibrator from SMAP via
In the new GUI, open the acquired bead stacks by clicking on
The output file is automatically set but can be adjusted as desired (
: arbitrary (this works for any PSF engineering modality)
: 10 nm (the value you took as ∆z when acquiring the bead stacks)
: 50 (this takes the central 50 frames for cross-correlation)
: 25 (This option discards beads that are too close to each other in the maximum intensity projection)
in case you acquired the bead stacks with EM gain (this affects the mirroring of the reconstructed data later)
the PSF calibration starts a new window with results figures opens that gets
The different tabs of the results figure contain the following information:
: Overview over the maximum intensity projections of the individual stacks.
Profile of the PSF along z
Profile of the PSF along x
frame against fitted z for every bead; the range with a linear relationship between the 2 can be used for 3D

The ROI manager can be accessed in the
It shows an overview of the measured field
of view, a list and picture of segmented ROIs, as well as their coordinates and important parameters
sets parameters for the visual representation in the ROI manager.
Imax for sites can be set to 0.1 to get the same brightness for all localizations shown in the ROI manager.

Many segment or analysis plugins can be also found in the main
The filtered and drift corrected superresolution image can be segmented for NPC manually or automatically.

before running the plugin. If only a part of the image should be segmented, additionally check

All simulated nuclear pores are added to the
and can be used for any analysis.
This function was used to quantify the diameter of rings in the Ex-SIM experiment (Figure 1, Supplementary Figure 2)
to calculate the local expansion factor.
Select a Tiff file. If the pixel size is not recognized from the Tiff metadata, you can define it yourself after line 19.
In line 47 you can select the width (sigma) of the Gaussian used for blurring. If you set it to empty (
]) the width is used as a free fitting parameter.
Zoom into the image until you can easily identify nuclear pores

Use the data cursor to select centers of individual nuclear pores. These get marked in the image. An additional window opens that displays the image, the starting model, the fitted model and the residuals.
